domino is attempting to be a tool i can use to collage thought fragments in a presentable way

i'm using pug to generate the html so i can edit the scripts/style/etc separately rather than in one long html file
usually i make my tools in typescript via create-react-app (without react)--doing it raw (and now via pug) has been surprisingly easy
everything is a single standalone html file that makes a copy of itself when you export a project
for ease of distribution, i think it's essential that tools export to a single standalone html file (when possible)
this page is both an exported domino project and the domino editor
you can customise the styling of the board by editing the css of your export
i like the idea that just by distributing an export you're also distributing the tool for someone to create their own
that exported board is now an editor that makes boards in your customised style
i need to clean up the html/css/javascript now things are solidifying--want it to be robust straight forward to modify
"domino" because putting thoughts with something in common adjacent to each other reminded me of matching dominoes
##blog post##read more about the inspiration and goals of domino on my blog

##blog post##a self-replicating and mutating tool?
this has some side-effects on how users get access to updates
but any changes you have made will need to be reapplied again manually--*'merged'* in software parlance
domino is released as a single domino board (this one). to update a local copy, you simply replace it with a copy of this board
users?--or participants in a software ecosystem?
every exported board is a backup of the specific editor version used to create it
consequently it may not be worth the effort to update
if the editor was functional enough to create the exported board, then it's probably sufficient for future edits too
you can, of course, import the board into a more up to date copy of domino if that isn't the case
the selectors beginning with `.domino-card-` are just examples, you can add any number of your own as long as the class starts with `domino-card-`
the proliferation of updates to domino is beyond my individual control
perhaps someone else develops a more popular variant
perhaps a more popular variant emerges organically from generations of small changes made by individuals
there are parallels with open source software, and parallels with memes and remix culture

##moving cards##i probably need to add some more powerful tools for moving cards around
you can only move one card at once, and you can only move it to somewhere you can see
what if you could drop cards into am intermediate holding area then drag them back out where you want them?
a couple people recommend twemoji to me. looks promising

is it possible to embed this rather than externally linking it?

i'd like it to work offline
different platforms support different emoji and users can't be certain that the icon they choose will be visible to someone else
##emoji##card icons are intended to be emoji, but...
are there emoji polyfills? are the javascript emoji libraries out there too heavy for this tool?
some emoji seem to get rendered as text instead of emoji...
alternatively (or additionally?) i'd like to add an editor similar to broider for making custom icons
it'd be nice to have an emoji picker...
